turns.content: whats the IP to ping to check nVidia Geforce now service latency?

To check the latency of NVIDIA GeForce Now service, you can use the following IP address to ping:

`ping latencytest.fra02.nvidia.com`

This will allow you to measure the latency between your device and NVIDIA's server located in Frankfurt, Germany. You can also replace "fra02" in the above IP address with other locations like "ams", "par", "sto", "dub", "mad", "lhr", "mil", "lis", "vie", "waw", "ams" or "cdg" to test the latency from different locations.

Keep in mind that latency can be affected by many factors, including your internet connection, network congestion, and distance from the server. Therefore, a single ping test may not provide a complete picture of your overall latency to the service.

▲ (Doms-MBP.local) examples [compass] ping latencytest.fra02.nvidia.com
ping: cannot resolve latencytest.fra02.nvidia.com: Unknown host
▲ (Doms-MBP.local) examples [compass] ping latencytest.dub1.nvidia.com

It seems like there might be an issue resolving the DNS name `latencytest.fra02.nvidia.com`. In this case, you can try pinging a different server location, like the Dublin server you tested:
```
ping latencytest.dub1.nvidia.com
```
This should allow you to measure the latency between your device and NVIDIA's server located in Dublin, Ireland. As mentioned before, keep in mind that latency can be affected by many factors, and a single ping test may not provide a complete picture of your overall latency to the service.
ping: cannot resolve latencytest.dub1.nvidia.com: Unknown host

If you're receiving an "Unknown host" error message when trying to ping `latencytest.dub1.nvidia.com`, it's possible that there is an issue with your DNS resolution or your network connection.

You can try the following troubleshooting steps:

1. Check your internet connection: Ensure that your device is connected to the internet and that your connection is stable.
2. Check your DNS settings: Make sure that your DNS settings are configured correctly. You can try changing your DNS settings to use a public DNS service like Google DNS (8.8.8.8 and 8.8.4.4) or Cloudflare DNS (1.1.
